pages.transcription:
Rosebud, S. Dak.
May 22 1903
My dear Uncle
I will send you Tomorrow
twenty six red drawings, some of the
heads there are three and four but
different positions. I have got 
twenty oil portraits finished. I have
not been working too hard.
Chief Sorrel Horse is sitting for one
now he has the reputation of stealing
more horses from other tribes of Indians
than any Indian he like very much
to tell about it.
I will send the oil portraits to
my Father as he has a lot of my
Indian frames and he can just as
well frame them for me.
I hardly know what my plans

are for the Summer it is too hot
to work during then and the Indians
do not like to sit.
These Indians do pretty well in the
Summer they are hired at a $1.50
a day to fix the wagon roads
all Summer The result is the roads
and bridges are in good condition
and then it gives employment to the
Indians, it would be a good idea I
think if all reservations would do this.
Tell Aunt Emma I received her
postal from Munich.
Love to you both
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
4218

Rosebud. S. Dak.
May 24. 1903.
My dear Uncle Ed
I received a postal from
you and Aunt Emma from Rothenburg
also letter from you, am so glad
you were pleased with Rothenburg it
is a delightful peaceful artistic old
Town.
You surely have had a long trip
you and Aunt Emma enjoy your
trips so much and get so much
out of them not only in pleasure
but education as well and besides?
have so much to show to your relatives
and friends both in conversation photos and curios
which is a pleasure and education to
them us well, well you both deserve
such good fortune.
I am getting along all right

working every day, am gaining in
health that is my nerves are getting
stronger am sleeping better and have
a good appetite take lots of exercise
and am taking better care of my self
than ever before; if I had known years
ago what I now know things would
have been different with me. I have
had experiences and am profiting by it.
I will send the Indian portraits to
my Father soon to frame am waiting
for them to dry enough to varnish
out, think you will like them as well
if not better than any have painted.
I can not find a room with
the ceiling high enough to paint the
full life size pictures I wrote you
about have been thinking of having
a rough shack built for the
purpose which would cost about
4218

$50.00 I think but I could paint several
pictures in it. These Indians have so
many Indian clothes and are the very
finest types I have been to.
It would be a good idea to get
a full life size picture of
Geronimo Joseph and Red Cloud
in full costume.
No I will not allow any thing to
interfere with my work it is of more
importance to me than any thing
else.
I do not blame you for longing
to get back to your beautiful home
at Lake Geneva and to your farm
which is so beneficial to your health
and such a pleasure to you.
I hardly know what my plans
are for this summer, will take a
rest for two months any way
and do nothing but be out doors
5-24-03

Next Winter I want to go to the
Flat Head Indians also to the
Blackfeet have not visited those
Indians yet.
Thurber has got some of my red
drawings I will write home to send
them own to your Office. I am in
doubts whether I will have an 
exhibition at Thurbers again, it is
too expensive. I think I can sell
enough pictures on the outside to keep
me going and those I have left will
keep all right and later on they can
be sold as a collection same as those
I sold to Mr Butler, don't you think
that a better plan? Thurber has several
of my Indian portraits now I
have a good notion to have them
sent to my Father and put them
away for me. 
Love to you and Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew. 
Elbridge.

Rosebud. S. Dak.
June 1. 1903.
My dear uncle
Just received Aunt Emmas
postal from Paris stating you were to
sail that day. 
Thurber has got two of my pictures
that I want you to see on is Chief
High Pipe and the other Chief Picket Pin
both are noted Chiefs, Picket Pin has
been in several fights a book has been
written about him. and High Pipe 
is a fine orator he has a wonderfully fine
voice very powerful and has considerable
influence with the Sioux Indians
I will write to Thurber and have him
send the two pictures to your Office for
you to inspect.
Chief Turning Bear is sitting for me
now he is a good type will paint
two pictures of him, there are several noted
Indians that I wish to paint yet
Crow Dog among them it was he who
shot Spotted Tail I saw him the other
day and he promised to come and sit for me
he is a fine type of an Indian.

but the Indians do not like him because
he killed Spotted Tail. he seems to be a hard
worker he hauls quite a little freight
from Valentine Neb some 32 miles from here.
I guess I will remain right here all
Summer and next Fall go to the
Flat head Indians in Montana.
I have sent 14 Indian portraits
to my Father to frame.  
With love to you and Aunt Emma
and all at The Lake
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
4218

Rosebud. S. Dak.
June 4. 1903.
My dear Uncle Ed. 
I have written to my Father to
send the pictures to your office address in
Chicago soon as they are framed and
if you have room wish you would please
put them in the vault I have also
written to the Museum in Philadelphia
to send the four pictures they have of
mine to your office it is better and
safer to have them there than in Harvard.
I think you will like the last lot
of pictures. 
With love to you and Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
P.S. Mr Dorsey has been here this week
getting Indian curios.

[[PICTURES TAKEN ON STORAGE   PHONE RED 1196
WILLIAM MORRIS
ART DEALER
248 Sutter Street
FRAMING A SPECIALITY -- letterhead]]
San Francisco, Sept 28 1903
My dear Uncle Ed         ans'd 10/16/03
I left Rosebud on account 
of the heat it was too hot to work
so came to San Francisco and
am painting some and resting.
An Art dealer here handles my
Indian pictures.
When convenient wish you would
go to my parents home and see
the Indian portraits. I sent some
time ago two Indian portraits to
your office in Chicago for your inspection
have not heard how you liked them.
My trouble does not intefere with
my work I will not allow it to.
I am in hopes and expect to
be free again soon I hope so
I came West as I thought it

[[PICTURES TAKEN ON STORAGE   PHONE RED 1196
WILLIAM MORRIS
ART DEALER
248 Sutter Street
FRAMING A SPECIALITY
San Francisco,______________190   -- letterhead]]
best to and soon am going North
of here for Indians I want to
remain West until matters are
settled in the East. I have had
enough sorrow to last me the
remainder of my life, it has changed
me for years from what I was intended to
be cheerful & happy. but now I
am all right again and will
allow nothing to put me back.
The red drawings take well here.
Shall be glad to hear from you
Love to you and Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
248 Sutter St.
9-28-03

[[THE PALACE HOTEL
O. E. WILLIAMS, Prop. -- letterhead]]
UKIAH, CAL., Dec 4 1903
My dear Uncle Ed, 
Dr Hudson who is
employed by the Field
Columbian Museum took
me out to the Ukiah Indians
who live some four miles
from here this afternoon
he is a fine man and
well pasted on the Indians
he has visited.
The Ukiahs are small
fat people the men all
mostly have a mustache
and whiskers and most
of them speak English
the are the most difficult
Indians to get to sit

every thing must be done
secretly and no white
man must see the pictures
on Indians either and
no Indian must know
that he or she are sitting
for the picture, but
two have promised to
come and sit for me
one of them is the head
man of the tribe.
These Indians make
fine baskets, they bought
the land they live
and farm on and
are very industrious
You probably know
Mrs Grace Hudsons 
work she was employed
by the Museum to do
some work for them.
They have a ranch way 
4218

[[THE PALACE HOTEL
O. E. WILLIAMS, Prop.
UKIAH, CAL.,_______________190  -- letterhead]]
up in the mountains
here.
He had a large collection
of baskets which he sold
to the Government.
He wished me to tell
you that he had called
at your Office to see
several times but
you were in Europe
he also wished me to
tell you that he was
still alive and hoped
some time to meet you.
I am gaining now
my nerves are getting
stronger and I hope
to remain with the
12-4-03

the Indians now until
am through with them
all. 
Your affectionate
nephew
Eldridge.

[[PALACE HOTEL
O.E. WILLIAMS, Prop. -- letterhead]]
arrived 12/10
UKIAH, CAL., Dec 4 1903
My dear Uncle Ed
I came here
yesterday The Ukiah
Indians are here they
are fine basket makers
Mrs Grace Hudson lives
here I have called on her
she thinks I will be able
to get them to sit for
me.
I am still some nervous
but am gaining and
am in hopes to be
better than ever soon.
An Artist who paints
Indians and loves that
life and the Indians

also has a great field
before him, coming here
I find that there is another
tribe some thirty miles
North of here which I
wish to visit.
I shall be glad to hear
from you. 
Love to Aunt Emma 
Your affectionate
nephew
Eldridge.
4218

The Palace Hotel
UKIAH, CAL., Dec 10 1903
My dear Uncle 
Yours received 
You are right I have
had enough experience for
one man and now that
matters are settled I will
commence to be my self
and I hope better than ever.
Mrs Burbank I believe has
written you in regard to
her pictures, I do not know
whether my Father sent you
all the pictures or not
if not some of Mrs B
pictures may be in Harvard.
I have finished some
red drawings of the

Poma Indians here they are
here with the Ukiahs they
are very difficult to get
to pose the hardest yet I
have had any thing to do
with, they say when they
die they do not wish any
one to see them not even
from a picture. The Poma I have
drawn is quite a noted
Indian some 80 years old.
Dr Hudson here is very kind
to me and through his
help (who has known them for
years and speaks their
language) I get them to
sit for me. Mrs Hudson
is a fine painter of Indians.
You probably have seen
her work she paints mostly
Indian children and Papooses.
I shall here after avoid 
4218

[[Arlington Hotel
GEO. HAUGSTED, Prop.
UKIAH, CAL.,______________190  -- letterhead]]
all trouble.
When I get a lot of
drawings will send them
to you.
I hope it will not be
long before I will be in
better shape than ever was
before and I see no reason
why not. I want to
spend the remainder of my
life with the Indians.
I am young yet but
have had enough experiences
for an old man 90 years
old but that is passed
now.
I find several tribes of 
12-10-03

Indians in California of
course they are pretty much
civilized these Indians
here speak English fairly
good they farm and
make baskets and
make beads just as
the Zuni's do and out of
the same material.
You will hear good
reports from me from
now on.
Your affectionate nephew
Eldridge.

[[Arlington Hotel     Main 281
GEO HAUGSTED, Prop.
UKIAH, CAL., Dec 12 1903
My dear Uncle Ed. 
Well I am getting back into
my old self again hard
at work I am only making
red drawings here as these
Indians have no costumes
and new a mustache and
whiskers they say they always
wore them, yesterday I drew
the Chief of the tribe he
has rheumatism badly he
says before the whites came
to this country the Indians
never had rheumatism or
consumption. Some of the
Indians have taken a fancy

to making very small baskets
some of them this size three circles--image
they are bought up very
readily. 
I received a letter from Mr
Tunies? asking me to call
on a Mr Purdy the famous
bulb man he is known the
World over for his bulbs you
and Aunt Emma probably
know of him he is a very
interesting man to meet
he has written an article on
basketry of these Indians here.
he is very much interested
in Indians around here has
studied their langague, he
told me his brother in Law
sold you that expensive
fine basket you have, bought
some 15 years ago
Mr Purdy is well acquainted
4218

[[Arlington Hotel
GEO HAUGSTED, Prop.
UKIAH, CAL.,___________190  -- letterhead]]
with Burbank the potatoe
man he came here from near
Lowell. Mass. he lives
not far from here some
50 miles I may go and
see him on my return.
These Indians speak better
English than any tribes I
have been to but one very
difficult to get to pose
as when they die their
belongings are burned and
they do not want any
picture of them left behind
they live in comfortable houses
the Government has nothing
to do with them the are
12-17-03

entirely independent.
The children go to the
Catholic School located
on their land. the one
I visited yesterday have
extensive hop fields and
employ a white man to
manage it for them and
that tribe has $2000.00 in
the bank. They make their
bread principally of acorns
I ate some of it and liked it
very much.
I do not know how
long will remain here.
Am thinking of going to
the Hupa Valley Indians
They are not so civilized
as these Indians are. 
Your affectionate 
newphew
Elbridge.

[[Arlington Hotel      PHONE 281
GEO. HAUGSTED, Prop. -- letterhead]]
UKIAH, CAL. Dec 16 1903
My dear Uncle Ed
Yours just received. 
I delivered your message to
Dr Hudson he is very anxious
to meet you and to see your
library, he is a great
help to me here but
these Indians are hard
to manage. I want to
remain here until get
quite a number of good
types.
You can rest assured
that here after I will avoid
unpleasant things.

We are having a rainy spell
now and keeps me from
getting out where the
Indians live, when they
come to town, sometimes
I can get them to sit
but it is hard work as
they come to shop and look
around and do not want
to be bothered. Dr Hudson
is very enthusiastic over
my red drawings. His
wife has an exhibition
now in San Francisco of
Indians mostly children.
Soon as I get some more
red drawings will send
them to you.
I am nicely situated here
and like it very much.
There are several tribes of Indians
in California that I never heard of 
before 
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.

[[THE PALACE HOTEL    Telephone, Main 21
Geo. Haugsted, Proprietor
T. Forse, Chief Clerk -- letterhead]]
Ukiah, California, Dec 24 1903
My dear Uncle
Yours received and
am glad Mrs B's pictures have
been delivered to Mr Thurber.
I will send you today by
Express some red drawings,
now some of the heads look
like Irishmen & tramps but
all of them are full blooded
Ukiah & Como Indians. Some of
these Indians tell me that years
ago they did not wear a mustache
or beard then some say they
always wear hair on their face,
however they do now.
I am doing my utmost
to be my old self again

[[THE PALACE HOTEL      Telephone, Main 21
Geo. Haugsted, Proprietor
T. Forse, Chief Clerk
Ukiah, California, _________190  -- letterhead]]
and am gaining right
along gaining in weight
sleep better and eat better I
take long walks every day.
Hope you will like the
red drawings Dr Hudson*
thinks they are the best work
I have done he is very enthusiastic
over the Indians and
speaks Ukiah very good.
He has written an article
about Indian work for a
magazine which is very
good and interesting, his
territory is California
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
12-24-03

[[THE PALACE HOTEL      Telephone, Main 21
Geo. Haugsted, Propietor
T. Forse, Chief Clerk -- letterhead]]
Ukiah, California, Dec 27 1903
My dear Uncle
Yours of Dec 22nd
received. 
The Paper Mills Co
215 Wabash Ave own
33 of the Indian plates
and the Chicago Colortype
Co own 21 plates. Mr
Harvey can get these
reproductions by writing
to them.
I do not know what
they could be bought for
a friend of mine bought
8 for one dollar but
think they could be

[[THE PALACE HOTEL      Telephone, Main 21
Geo. Haugsted, Proprietor
T. Forse, Chief Clerk
Ukiah, California,____________190  -- letterhead]]
(2) 
bought for much less in
large quantities.
The Chicago Colortype Co
Chicago I am sure will
reach them but their
address could be obtained
from The Paper Mills Co
Mr E. U. Kimbark is one of
the proprietors.
Yes I know Mr Dorsey
buys curios for Mr
Harvey. I met him at
Rosebud S. Dak and he
bought a lot of Indian
curios there, fine ones.
I sent you 12 red drawings
I have thought if it
12-27-03

[[THE PALACE HOTEL      Telephone, Main 21
Geo. Haugsted, Proprietor
T. Forse, Chief Clerk
Ukiah, California,__________190  -- letterhead]]
would be a good idea to
send Mr Harvey some of
these red drawings seems
to me they would sell
well as they are the originals
I could furnish them for
$10.00 each.
I have gained 7 pounds 
since have been here.
Your affectionate nephew 
Elbridge.

[[PICTURES TAKEN ON STORAGE      PHONE RED 1196
WILLIAM MORRIS
ART DEALER
248 Sutter Street
FRAMING A SPECIALTY -- letterhead]]
San Francisco, Jan 7 1904
My dear Uncle Ed
I came here on my way
to the Hoopa Indians the cheapest &
best way is by boat from here
to Eureka then 45 miles by stage
The man who transfers baggage told
me the boat left next day at
9 A.M. but afterwards I was in the
paper that the boat did not leave
until 1:30 so when I went to the
1:30 boat my trunk was not
there and by the time I had located
it the boat had gone. and I
am glad of it, as friends who
have been there tell me that the
Winter is a bad time to go so
much rain and snow that in the
Summer it is fine there

[[PICTURES TAKEN ON STORAGE      PHONE RED 1196
WILLIAM MORRIS
ART DEALER
248 Sutter Street
FRAMING A SPECIALTY
San Francisco,___________190  -- letterhead]]
so have decided to go to Yuma &
work down there with those Indians
then in the Summer go North.
The trouble in going to places where it
is cold is to get a room with a
North light and a stone in it. so
hereafter will go South in Winter &
North in Summer.
You can address me to
Yuma Arizona
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge A. Burbank.

Yuma Arizona.
Jan 11. 1904.
My dear Uncle.
I am nicely fixed here
am living at the Indian
Agency built on top of a hill
have a large house all to my
self and a nice place to eat in
The climate is simply grand
here in the Winter.
I will get some good subjects
here, there are three different
tribes in an around here.
Yesterday I witnessed a foot
ball game by the Yuma Indians.
I am so much better sleep
good and have a good
appetite only get lonesome
sometimes. Expect to remain here a few
weeks.
An Indian is to come and
sit for me this noon. They

are very poor, depend a good deal
on the fancy work. They make for
a living, the Government furnishes
the old ones with rations.
These Indians are very supersticious
same as the Mojaves & Ukiahs
but I will be able to get all I
want to sit for me.
With love to all
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge A. Burbank.
1068

Yuma. Arizona.
Jan. 13. 1904.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am getting some good
red drawings here and am
lucky to get them as they are
so supersticious, an old Indian
who sat for me said to the others
that five years had been taken off
from his life.
Soon as become better acquainted
with them will get them to pose
for oil pictures.
I witnessed a cremation today
a Yuma child died at three
oclock this morning and at
ten oclock the body was burned
up. I went to the house where
the body was and some fifty
Indians had gathered there and
were crying and mourning making
a sad noise.
I left them and went to where
the cremating was to take place

some 100 yards away and there
was some logs piled in the shape
of a box there was some logs
for the bottom of box and on
the sides and one end logs and
on the outside of logs dried grass
piled up against the logs, pretty
soon they came with the body
all crying out loud (before they
came I had finished a sketch of
the log oven and they tell me at
the Agency it is the only picture
in existence of one) they laid the
body down in front of the logs
& cried some more then placed it
inside and covered the body all
over with logs like a roof to a
house then placed blankets on top
of it all and touched a match
to it, they remained there until it
all burned up, and now tonight
they are burning up the house the
child lived in and the parents go
and live on another part of the
reservation.

I like it here have good home
cooking.
I am gaining right along and
dont want to return home until
have been to all the tribes and I
can do that in some six or seven
years more.
The Yuma children are quite
good looking I see all the
Indian children I wish to as
am stopping where the school
is located.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge A. Burbank.
1-13-04

Yuma. Arizona.
Jan 17 1904.
My dear Uncle Ed
Yours just received.
I also received a letter from
Mr E. W. Sawyer stating he was
coming here. I am so glad as he
will be nice company for me
and my experience among the
Indians I will gladly give to him.
He is very wise in taking up the
Indian subject and he will find
all the subjects he wants here.
I think we both can work from
the same model, two of us can live
cheaper than one. 
It is just the place for him to
come to for rheumatism so dry
and mild and even tempered very
seldom rains.
I have a fine place to board, home
cooking he can board at same place
and I have two big rooms another
bed can be put up for him. I
am so glad he is coming he will

be so much company for me I
wont have to take my long walks
alone.
I am afraid I wont have any
thing in the St Louis exhibit, several
months ago I filled out a blank
sent me but another was to be sent
which I have not received.
I am painting just as good as
ever did have a fine subject sitting
for a painting now painted up
in Yuma style. 
These Yuma keep up their old
customs and cling to them as much
as any tribe I have been to they live
in the same kind of houses as they
always did and wear their hair the
same and still keep up their old
way of disposing of their dead
and until the Southern Pacific R.R.
came here dressed as they used to
mostly naked but when the R.R.
came here the Indians were asked
to wear more clothes.
I have written to Mr Sawyer and
expect in a few days he will be
here. I remember him an his

brother when he was a boy
The other day I walked down to
where that boys body was cremated and
saw the Father sad looking building
a new home I stopped and talked
with him awhile he did not feel
much like talking he had the frame all
up for his new home and was
filling in between the willows with
mud.
I will write and have Mr
Faber send the $120.00 to Herb
and I will have a check account
with Herb.
I am expecting the balance of
the money due me soon from the sale
of these Indian pictures and soon
as get it will send it to Herb.
I am so glad that I am getting
to be my old self again am gaining
in weight all the time had to let
my vest out yesterday it was so
tight.
The Indian I am painting had a
slight mustache but I prevailed
1-17-04

upon him to shave it off, very few
of them wear any hair on their face.
The old abandoned Fort where I
stop is on the California side of Yuma
am told it was built in the forties
to protect emigrants traveling across
the country, it is the first time that
I ever stopped at an Indian school
and am surprised to see how well
taken care of the Indian children are and
well behaved, now that they are
becoming better acquainted with me
they talk to me and most of them speak
good English.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge A. Burbank.
1070

Yuma. Arizona.
Jan 24. 1904
My dear Uncle Ed
Yours received with
Mr Harveys letter enclosed
am obliged to you for
writing to him.
I saw another cremating
scene yesterday this time
it was a man 35 years
old. I saw the whole
thing, made a sketch of
the ceremony at the house
also made a sketch of the
cremating log oven.
I was right in the midst
of them when the body was

placed before the cremating
place and witnessed that
ceremony dont care to see it
again never heard or saw
such grief. I remained until
the fire got to burning the
body then I thought it was
time to leave.
When I got there his trunks
including his cloths and
valuables were burning.
I rather expected Mr Sawyer
to day hope he will come
I am getting along all
right have finished two
oil portraits and tomorrow
will have another one finished
also finished several red
drawings.
I may paint a composition
picture here some scene
1071

in an Indian house, probably
will remain here until hot
weather drives me away.
I get good healthy food here
and does me good am
gaining all the time.
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge A. Burbank.
1-24-04

Yuma. Arizona.
Feb. 2. 1904.
My dear Uncle Ed.
My Indian portraits are
scattered here and there and I
have thought if it would not be
a good plan to get them together
and if the Field Museum will give
me space to hang them on the
wall in the Museum so they will
be of some benefit as it is now no
one sees them.
It wont be many years before
this Indian work will be a thing
of the past they are dieing off so
fast the older ones and genuine
Indians. I wish I could make
arrangements with the Museum
to paint Indian portraits for them
would paint them for $100.00 each and
in some 10 years could visit every
tribe in America and could make
red drawings for $10.00 each

now is a chance to get types of
every Indian tribe in America and
the Museum is so interested in this
Indian work. Wish you would let
me know what you think about it.
I am painting quite a number
of the Yuma children they are very
interesting fine types.
I will send you some red drawings
soon.
I am gaining all the time,
Mr Butler who bought the 105
portraits of me writes me that the
Carnegie Institute want the loan of all
of his Indian portraits for a special
exhibition in Pittsburg says also
the Philadelphia Museum have
written him in regard to them
I guess the Phila" Museum people
wish when those 120 portraits hung
on their walls they had bought them.
but now I can get another
collection easy enough.
An old squaw is being cremated
to night, I saw the fire far
enough away so that I could
1072

not hear them cry.
There is only one Chief left of the
Yuma I have two red drawings of
him he will not sit for a portrait
in oil is afraid to.
Mr Sawyer has not arrived as
yet expect him soon however, from
here think I will go West to a
tribe of Indians some 150 miles from
here Then to Nevada as it will
be getting hot here by then, but
now the climate is fine.
If the Museum are willing I will

of fish.
I went to a steam ship office
in Los Angeles to inquire the
fair to Manilla which was
$335.50 1st cabin there and
back good for 4 months and
can have the time extended
It is too hot now to go
among the Indians that is
where I want to go on the
desert South of Los Angeles.
I have gained some 10 lbs
since have taken a rest
If it was not so far I would
send you all some fine fish
Yellow Tail Beracuda and
Sand Dabs. Yesterday I caught
a Shark on the line he was

5 feet long had to cut the hook

You can address me to

Your affectionate nephew

Oceanside. Cal.
Aug. 17. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am on my
way to Pala Cal. 24
miles from here where one tribe of the
Mission Indians are.
Eight miles from here
and two miles out
of my way to Pala
is the Ramona
Home where Helen
Jackson wrote Ramona.
I am going there on
my way to Pala.
You know they
have several places where

Ramona was supposed
to live but they have
proops enough here to
convince one this is
the place, The livery
stable where I hire
my team his brother
ownes the Ramona
ranch and he Told
me he worked on the
ranch years ago when
Helen Jackson was there
said he knew here
personally and he saw
her writing, said at
the time he was
hurt and in head
and that she used
him as on of the
characters in the story
called "Fillippi" (which

weigh 160 lbs I did

looped? had a fine

Then will go below
